fields.summary: Add test coverage for V4 related use cases

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description:
The expiry of a signature v4 presigned url should be based on the X-Amz-Expires parameter.

{quote}
X-Amz-Expires	

Provides the time period, in seconds, for which the generated presigned URL is valid. For example, 86400 (24 hours). This value is an integer. The minimum value you can set is 1, and the maximum is 604800 (seven days).

A presigned URL can be valid for a maximum of seven days because the signing key you use in signature calculation is valid for up to seven days. 
{quote}

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/sigv4-query-string-auth.html

It looks like we currently expire all signature v4 presigned urls after 15 minutes.
fields.summary: S3 signature v4 presigned url expiry is incorrect

comments.body:
[~vasya] So the URL you're using still needs to be converted to a signed URL, and it's that signed URL that you use to make the request. Ex:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/ShareObjectPreSignedURL.html

This takes the expiration into account when signing. Perhaps that is the issue?
[~jhalterman], it looked to me like we are currently enforcing that all signature v4 requests are within 15 minutes of the X-Amz-Date.
[~jhalterman], you have to wait. Freshly created urls works. Only after some time - I've tested for about 40 min - they are starting to fail.
[~jhalterman], your signed url does not work any more.

[~vasya] Thanks. Rebasing my original fix's branch off of maint-4.4, it looks like this was inadvertently broken again since I made my fix (which is why I wasn't seeing it). Will push another fix shortly...

See the commit in internal/dev-jhalterman-EUCA-13051-2 branch:

Commit: 3365360

Basically, validation of the Date slipped back into handling of V4 params based requests (as opposed to just validating the X-Amx-Expires header, relative to X-Amz-Date).
[~jhalterman], where is the date checked? (i.e. not before)
[~sjones] For pre-signed requests, the date is not validated by itself, just in relation to the expires param.
[~sjones] What is the expiration relative to the date? And what do you think the rule regarding dates should be - verify it's within the clock skew config?

[~jhalterman], I think aws/s3 rejects the request if the X-Amz-Date is more than 15 minutes in the future or if X-Amz-Date + X-Amx-Expires is in the past (I think we should allow for our configured clock skew here)
[~sjones] Just to be clear, you'd reject on +/- our clock skew, or 15 minutes +/- our clock skew?

[~jhalterman], I believe the expiry check should not allow +15 minutes, only our regular clock skew. For the date check we'd want to allow 15 minutes. The intent is to have the same checks as aws but also allow for a small amount of clock skew on the expiry validation.

[~sjones] So for a pre-signed request that is being submitted hours or days after the X-Amz-Date, how are those requests not always rejected by AWS? Aren't we either validating X-Amz-Date for pre-signed requests, or not?

[~jhalterman], a pre-signed request is valid for some period of time. The start of that time period is determined by the date (X-Amz-Date) and the end of that time period by the date + the expiry (X-Amz-Date + X-Amz-Expires). More specifically, if the current time is earlier than X-Amz-Date - 15 minutes the request should be rejected (not yet valid), if the current time later than X-Amz-Date + X-Amz-Expires + "our clock skew" the request should be rejected (expired)

It's still in regression, but check out internal/dev-jhalterman-EUCA-13051

Commit: 1e3b54a
[~jhalterman], looks good to me.
[~jhalterman], is this meant to be assigned to me to review?
[~tony] Yea, that was the intention.
Moving 4.4.0 Issues from Release Pending to Resolved
